user.biography: Not just a great valley, but a shrine to human foresight, the strength of granite, the power of glaciers, and the tranquility of the High Sierra.

node.text:
Throughout human history, songs have served as a catalyst for connection. Songs have continuously been used to celebrate one’s culture, bring people together and bring about the emotions that only music can surface. While we may be surrounded by human song on our day-to-day basis, we may also encounter them through the natural world around us. 

As a Global Important Bird Area, Yosemite is enriched by birdsongs throughout the park. Although birdsongs may sound like beautiful melodies for us, they can be a means to defend and impress. Many birds are territorial, meaning that they lay claim to specific areas. Songs allow them to identify these regions as their own and are often used to defend this space. In other circumstances, male birds use songs to attract females. Melodies give these birds a chance to show off and impress potential mates. Being mindful of the distinctive soundscapes around us can help us differentiate and identify birds we encounter anywhere in the world. 

With 262 different species documented inside the park, there are endless opportunities to enjoy birding in Yosemite. Just a stroll through the park can introduce you to a whole new world of sound and flight right above your head. For more information on birds and birdwatching in Yosemite, please visit https://www.nps.gov/yose/planyourvisit/birdwatching.htm. 

[Video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SbkqNiiwHXg]

node.text:
Today marks the 25th anniversary of the 1996 Happy Isles rockfall.  At 6:52 pm on July 10, 1996, two blocks with a combined volume of about 30,000 cubic meters and weighing about 90,000 tons broke loose from high on the southeast part of Glacier Point, hitting the valley floor near Happy Isles. In terms of volume, this equates to about 2000 SUVs dropping onto the valley floor at the same time. The impacts of the blocks generated an airblast with wind speeds up to 280 miles per hour, comparable to that of a Category 5 hurricane or a F5 tornado on the Fujita Scale. 

The airblast uprooted and snapped about one thousand trees, which damaged buildings and caused one fatality and several serious injuries.  Following the airblast, a dense cloud of pulverized rock blanketed the area with coarse sand and dust.  Dust rose rapidly into the air and plunged the Happy Isles area into darkness for several minutes.  Search and rescue personnel spent the next several days searching for victims in extremely challenging conditions but fortunately discovered no further casualities. 

Although tragic, this event would have been much more consequential if the rockfall had occurred just a few hours earlier.  Nevertheless, the 1996 Happy Isles rockfalls remains one of the most devastating rockfalls in Yosemite’s history.

[Video: Helicopter footage showing the destruction of the rockslide opens the video showing hundreds of downed trees and rocks on the valley floor. On-the-scene footage of the destruction at Happy Isles is then shown. Emergency search and rescue teams as well as search dogs scour the rubble searching for survivors and clearing the debris. Footage of destroyed building exteriors and interiors are also featured.]

node.title: Aftermath of the 1996 Happy Isles Rockfall

node.text:
“He is the mountain streams’ own darling, the humming-bird of blooming waters, loving rocky ripple-slopes and sheets of foam as a bee loves flowers, as a lark loves sunshine and meadows. Among all the mountain birds, none has cheered me so much in my lonely wanderings, —none so unfailingly. For both in winter and summer he sings, sweetly, cheerily, independent alike of sunshine and of love, requiring no other inspiration than the stream on which he dwells”. – John Muir

The muse of Mr. Muir’s prose is none other than the Ouzel, or American dipper (Cinclus mexicanus). Looking much like a dipping, wading, swimming, and occasionally flying, cobble with bluish-gray feathers, dippers are found almost exclusively along the rivers and streams in which they live. They feed on larval stage water insects and can be seen moving leaves and rocks under the water in search of a meal. Nests are built along the streams on rocky, protected, areas above flood lines. Dippers need clear, unpolluted waters and, as such, are considered an indicator species of water quality. While they remain in much of their original habitat range, they have been extirpated from streams that became too polluted for them to survive. 

Very often seen from the banks and bridges in Yosemite, their movements and behaviors can be mesmerizing to watch. Dippers frequently make short chirps, however their melodic songs can brighten the even dreariest of winter days.
#Yosemite #NationalPark #Ouzel #AmericanDipper #Cinclus

node.text:
Join Ranger Kate and her special canine assistants for some pollinator science.
Pollinators come in all shapes and sizes! So do your household pets. You can try this experiment at home with your own pet to see how effective they are as pollinators!
Step 1: Find a few jars or cups of different shapes and sizes.
Step 2: Give them some fancy paper petals or leaves to 
look like flowers!
Step 3:  Perhaps create some paper wings or antennae 
to adorn your favorite pet…
Step 4:  Get a few small treats for your pets to serve as 
their ‘nectar reward’ inside the flower.
Step 5: Test your pet-pollinator!
How many jars did they get a reward from?  Why? 
Did they have any specific technique? 
Please share your results in the comments! 
BONUS if you can research and find out what pollinator in nature your pet is the most like!
Remember- some pollinators are more effective than others, but it’s still important that they are here on this planet doing their job.
Even if your pet-pollinator isn’t very ‘effective,’ what matters most is that they are very loved!

node.title: Pollinator Science with Ranger Kate & Friends

node.text:
We are reposting our video of Shelton Johnson discussing hidden histories for African American History Month. A story that has become uncovered can become buried simply by the steady stream of newer stories, so it seems pertinent to reinforce this one. What other underrepresented stories are out there that we should recover and amplify?
#AfricanAmericanHistoryMonth

node.title: Ranger Shelton Johnson Speaks about African American History Month 2021

node.text:
On a recent winter afternoon, we watch two female common mergansers diving in the Merced River, searching the river bottom rocks for an aquatic critter for lunch.

These large ducks, with a distinctive pointed orange bill, can be found in Yosemite Valley all year. In early summer you might catch a mother herding her ducklings along the riverbank scooting from cove to cove on the Merced River.

node.title: Mergansers hunting in the Merced River

node.text: Join Ranger Alex in another conversation with one of Yosemite's misunderstood animals.

node.title: Misunderstood Animals with Ranger Alex: Episode Bat

node.accessibility_caption: Up close photo of rock with a variety of lichen on it in varying shades of green.

node.text:
Often in life, we find ourselves joining with others to accomplish what we can’t do on our own. Working together as a team may seem like an inherently human activity, but did you know that other organisms do this too? 

Found in a variety of diverse habitats, lichens are complex life forms that are made up of two different organisms: a fungus and an alga. Although they belong to two separate kingdoms, Fungi and Protista, these organisms work together in a harmonious symbiotic partnership. Fungi, the dominant partners within the relationship, do not contain chlorophyll and rely on other organisms to provide them nutrition. Algae, on the other hand, do photosynthesize, meaning that they are able to convert light from the sun to chemical energy that they can use as fuel to survive. When these two organisms join forces, the algal partner provides food to the fungus, and jointly thrive as a lichen. 

Lichens are a key component to our world’s natural mosaic. By working together, fungi and algae provide the colorful adornments that you can find lining rocks, trees, and other surfaces all around us. What other relationships have you spotted in nature?

node.accessibility_caption: A mother bear and baby bear standing in a pathway. The mother bear has a purple tag on its ear with the number 9.

node.text:
Happy National Wildlife Day! Visitors to Yosemite Valley last fall were more likely than usual to see a bear during their trip. Acorns dropping from Yosemite Valley’s black oaks were perfectly timed with black bears entering hyperphagia, a period when bears are looking for big calorie boosts (up to 20,000 calories every day or eleven pounds of acorns) as they prepare for winter hibernation. Other fall food sources may have fallen flat, making the acorns in Yosemite Valley a particularly big draw for bears. It was truly a sight to behold! Despite normally being solitary animals, numerous bears were regularly foraging together in small areas due to the abundant food source. Sows were leading their cubs through their first acorn harvest and even exciting displays of the hierarchy among bears was playing out—with dominant bears (often the large males or defensive sows) chasing the more subordinate bears (often the smaller and younger bears) away from their feast.

In years like last year when acorns are abundant, the trees attract bears which in turn attracts the attention of thousands of enthralled visitors. While these displays are exciting to witness, the proximity of some of these bear-filled oaks to busy roads, trails, and development can create big hazards for bears. Rangers extensively and creatively managed these areas in order to keep people back and allow these bears to remain wild. Initially, rangers tried scaring the bears away from oaks near trails and roads, only to have them return a few minutes later. The bears quickly made it clear that they weren’t going anywhere as long as the acorn feast remained. These bears triggered massive crowds and huge traffic jams (“bear jams”), which created some chaotic situations. Ultimately, a temporary trail closure gave bears and people a bigger buffer, and rangers spent most of their shifts monitoring the situation, keeping people back, and educating thousands of people about the importance of giving wildlife space as they admired the agile tree climbing eating machines.

To learn more about bear safety and how to #KeepBearsWild, please refer to the link in our bio.

Photos by Drew Wharton

node.accessibility_caption: A mother bear and baby bear standing in a pathway. The mother bear has a purple tag on its ear with the number 9.
A park ranger stands next to a sign with messages about bears on it. A wooden cut out bear stand fifty feet away on the trail.
A large crowd of people of people stand along a wooden fence observing a bear just out of view. A wildlife ranger stands back.
Lanscape view from above of a hazy Tuolumne Meadows. Mountains are in the background.

node.text:
Which ecosystem makes up only 3% of Yosemite, but contains 30% of our known park species?

If you said meadows, you are correct! Yosemite National Park has over 3,000 meadows in the park ranging from 3,300 to over 12,000 feet in elevation. As biodiversity hotspots, these unique habitats support a large portion of our park’s wildlife populations. Meadows have the incredible ability to act as sponges, storing and filtering water, store carbon, provide food as well as pollution control. Filtered water from meadows in the Tuolumne River drainage directly benefits water consumers all the way downstream to the San Francisco Bay Area.
 
Meadows in the park also serve as reminders of how humans have actively shaped the land throughout Yosemite’s history. The people of the seven traditionally associated tribes have lived and traveled throughout these meadows for 10,000 years and maintained a mutual relationship with the land by harvesting plants and animals for food, shelter, and tools. Contemporary tribal members continue this relationship. When Europeans arrived in Yosemite 170 years ago, suppression of natural fires, the prohibition of cultural burning by native people and introduction of cattle and sheep grazing reduced below-ground root biomass in Yosemite’s meadows, resulting in a loss of carbon storage capacity in the park, and lead to encroachment by conifers reducing water levels. Over the years, park management, in consultation with the tribes, has strived to restore the health of meadows.

Today is the anniversary of the 1964 Wilderness Act. Most of these meadows were designated as wilderness in 1984, providing additional protection to undeveloped areas of the park. Staying on designated trails is the best way you can help our meadows thrive. Wherever you go in Yosemite, make sure to tread lightly and avoid decorating nature's meadows with footprints and tire tracks.

node.accessibility_caption: A brown entrance fee station next to the road. There is a ranger sticking their head out of the door, and a "Reservations required" sign standing in the foreground.

node.text:
Yosemite National Park remains open with reservations required despite recent California national forests closures. If you're visiting this Labor Day weekend, here are a few things to keep in mind as you #RecreateResponsibly:

•Be sure you're physically prepared and with proper equipment for your hike. Don't forget to bring and consume plenty of water and salty snacks.

•Fire restrictions are in effect inside the park: https://www.nps.gov/yose/planyourvisit/firerestrictions.htm

•While there are no large fires in Yosemite and air quality has been good to moderate, hazy or smoky conditions are possible from fires elsewhere in California. Check https://www.nps.gov/yose/learn/nature/aqmonitoring.htm for updates.

node.accessibility_caption: Historical photo of ranger standing in front of entrance station building with American flag flying

node.text:
Yosemite National Park is open despite the closure of California's national forests. Reservations are still required and fire restrictions are in effect below 8,000 feet. Wood and charcoal fires are only allowed in open picnic areas and campgrounds. Smoking is prohibited except inside closed vehicles, in open picnic areas and campgrounds, and in designated areas. Gas and alcohol stoves are allowed. Please use caution anytime you're using a stove, campfire, grill, or smoking. 

#Yosemite #NationalPark

Air quality in Yosemite has generally been good to moderate, but smoky conditions are possible based on weather patterns and fire activity.

node.accessibility_caption: A dome web suspended in air among branches and trees.

node.text:
Yosemite National Park is home to Half Dome, North Dome, Basket Dome, Lembert Dome, and Pothole Dome, just to name a few, but if you look carefully enough, you’ll find so many more domes than just these. Some domes, though, aren’t made of stone.

The Sierra Dome Spider (Neriene litigiosa) spins a curiously shaped web. Forgoing the simple planar structure stereotypical of spiders, this resident of the park (as well as through much of the Sierra Nevada and beyond) instead constructs a namesake dome between the branches of shrubs and trees or any solid support it can find. There it waits, upside-down at the very top, for its prey of small flies, gnats, and other smaller spiders to become entangled, and before the hapless creature can escape, the Sierra Dome Spider bites it, pulling it through the dome.

It’s challenging to know for certain why or how these spiders learned to spin so specific a shape, but regardless, their little homes complement well the greater terrain, reflecting in miniature the great monuments of Yosemite National Park.

node.accessibility_caption: A dome web suspended in air among branches and trees.
A dome web atop the leaves of a bush.
Close-up image of a Sierra dome spider atop its web.
The museum's giant sequoia with a large gash caused by lightning running down the tree's side.

node.text:
On Friday, July 30, at 4:30 pm, the giant sequoia tree in front of the Yosemite Museum was struck by lightning. A loud crack was heard throughout Yosemite Village over the roar of the heavy rain, followed by a flurry of falling bark and branches. When the rain finally cleared, park rangers and visitors gathered around the tree look for damage. The strike left a gash spiraling down the tree.

This sequoia was planted on November 11, 1926, as an eight-year-old sapling, replacing a recently planted sequoia that had died in 1925. The young sequoia marked the opening of the Yosemite Museum, which was the first museum building constructed in the National Park System. As sequoias do not naturally grow in Yosemite Valley, the museum sequoia was for many a first encounter with one of Yosemite’s red giants and it wasn't uncommon to see a ranger standing by the tree talking about it with visitors. 

In the days after the lightning strike, Yosemite’s forestry crew identified a large and growing crack 100 feet up the tree. The sequoia’s unstable state and its position near a number of buildings forced them to take the tree down. Starting from the top, branches and logs were cut piece by piece, eventually leaving behind a single stump where the young yet majestic tree once stood. 

Today, you can visit the stump across the walkway from the museum’s famous sequoia ring display and ponder nature’s ever fleeting presence during our own transient lives.

node.accessibility_caption: The museum's giant sequoia with a large gash caused by lightning running down the tree's side.
A large forestry truck with a metal basket reaching high onto a branch-less sequoia tree.
A large sequoia stump in the foreground, with the museum, a sequoia ring display, and an 'umacha in the background.
A black and white photo depicting the planting of a young sequoia tree, surrounded by multiple men.

node.text:
Last weekend, Yosemite National Park hosted its annual Knap-In event in the Yosemite Valley Indian Village. Knapping is the process of shaping flint, chert, obsidian, or other fracturing stone to create a stone tool or weapon and is a practice that has been conducted in Yosemite by associated tribes for thousands of years. Although often associated with prehistoric cultures, this tradition is still carried out around the world today and is a celebrated hobby amongst archaeologists and enthusiasts alike. 

Knappers at the event demonstrated proper knapping techniques, something that often takes years to master. Park rangers and visitors alike learned how to adequately fracture stone and form functionable blades using the same methods that have existed since early human history. This educational event served as a window into our own cultural past, keeping afloat age-old customs that may otherwise be forgotten in our fast-paced world.

What traditions do you maintain in your life?

node.text:
We’re not trying to trash talk, but let’s talk about TRASH! Before you head to the park this season, take a moment to think about how you’re planning to pack it in AND pack it out. Every year, our wilderness restoration crews remove illegal campsites in Yosemite’s wilderness, and along the way collect and remove trash. In 2019, the crew collected over 25 pounds of trash from the wilderness alone. The most common items found include aluminum foil, micro-trash, toilet paper, and even socks. To keep the wilderness clean for all, here are some helpful tips: 

•Don’t let foil spoil the wilderness! Aluminum foil is found in most fire rings. Contrary to popular belief, foil does not melt, but fragments into smaller pieces. Please refrain from throwing foil into your fire at the end of the night. 

•Micro-trash comes from many different sources. The greatest culprit is foil lined granola bar wrappers. Try to open bars so that the wrapper remains in one piece, instead of ripping off a tiny corner that can easily get dropped on the ground. Make sure to be aware of any small micro-trash that you might have dropped while snacking. 

•Bring resealable bags to put used toilet paper and sanitary products in. Toilet paper does not decompose as fast as you might think and must be packed out! 
 
•Try not to lose your socks, the ecosystem and your toes will thank you. 

If you find yourself in the wilderness this summer, please be mindful of your trash and pack it out!

A wildlife biologist stands next to a metal crate as she watches a collared Sierra Nevada bighorn sheep run away.

node.text:
On an early morning stroll in the park, you may be lucky enough to catch a glimpse of some of the world’s best climbers. Clinging to mountain walls, these daring individuals were once described by John Muir as the “bravest of all Sierra Mountaineers” and can only be spotted in some of the most extreme corners of the High Sierra. Contrary to modern day rock climbers, these stealthy creatures don’t rely on ropes and chalk for their ascents, but rather specialized hooves. With over 500 of them wandering the mountains today, the Sierra Nevada bighorn sheep are graceful animals that truly highlight the value of Yosemite’s wild and diverse landscape. 

Sierra Nevada bighorn sheep are the rarest mountain sheep in North America.  Ranging from off-white to brownish grey in color, they vary in weight between 140 to 220 pounds and stand up to three feet tall. Rams have characteristically immense curved horns that weight up to 15 pounds, while ewes have smaller, gently curved spiked horns. This species’ anatomical adaptations have assisted in their ability to scale great mountain walls: strong muscles and unique rubber-like pads on the bottom of their hooves allows for exceptional grip over irregular rock surfaces, allowing them to easily ascend monumentally steep terrain. These bighorn sheep are only found in the Sierras and are mostly spotted in rocky elevations above 10,000 feet. 

Following the arrival of western settlers, diseases decimated Sierra Nevada bighorn sheep populations, plunging population numbers to near extinction just 25 short years after the establishment of Yosemite National Park. Restoration efforts in the park led by the National Park Service and California Department of Fish and Wildlife began in the 1980’s after nearly seventy-five years of sheep absence. Successful sheep relocation efforts have raised the total number of sheep within park boundaries from 0 to over 75. 

Contemporary park biologists continue to monitor the Warren, Gibbs, and Cathedral bighorn sheep herds in their ancestral homeland.  Thanks to these magnificent recovery efforts, this species has been returned to its rightful place within the towering cliffs of the Sierra Nevada.

node.accessibility_caption: A tall wire board with the words "Yosemite Vision, Basketry in Yosemite" stands in the Valley Mall. Colorful sheets with text and images of baskets are attached detailing basketry's history in the park.

node.text:
Native inhabitants and visitors alike have found beauty in Yosemite’s giant trees, epic cliffs, and graceful wildlife for countless generations. These wonders of our natural world continuously impact millions each year, inspiring many to reflect on their own personal experiences with the landscape through various means of self-expression. 

From basketry to landscape paintings, art in all its forms has become an integral part of Yosemite and its cultural history. This week, we are hosting our annual Yosemite Visions Art initiative promoting artistic inspiration and creativity throughout the park. Interactive educational panels featuring a different artist can be found around the park and are equipped with materials for everyone to create their own Yosemite inspired pieces. All skill levels are invited to participate and celebrate art in Yosemite! 

Look for Yosemite Visions Art pop-ups now through August 26 in Yosemite Valley, the Tuolumne Grove of Giant Sequoias, Tuolumne Meadows, Glacier Point, and the Mariposa Grove.

node.text:
Have you ever stopped and wondered how many feet have walked on the trail through a meadow before you? A couple thousand? A couple million? Over time, footsteps can compact soil, reducing the meadow’s water-holding capacity, increasing erosion, and causing habitat fragmentation. 

Here in Yosemite, ecological restoration is an essential component in maintaining our park’s ecosystems. This work aims to help bring back critical natural processes after they have been harmed by misuse, allowing plants and animals to flourish in their environments. Restoration comes in a variety of forms: from sowing native seed, to planting seedlings, to decompacting informal trails, re-routing trails out of sensitive meadows and ecologically restoring the trail ruts. Throughout the year, park employees and volunteers head into the park’s wilderness to combat the harmful effects of constant human use, rehabilitating Yosemite one meadow at a time. By restoring ecological function around the park, we are helping to ensure that Yosemite remains a healthy ecosystem for future generations.

To learn more about ecological restoration projects in Yosemite, please visit https://www.nps.gov/yose/learn/nature/ecorestoration.htm
